content.description: Let <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function given by <math alttext="f of x, equals, the fraction with numerator x, and denominator, open parenthesis, x minus 4, close parenthesis, times, open parenthesis, x plus 2, close parenthesis, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> on the closed interval <math alttext="open bracket, negative 7, comma 7, close bracket " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Of the following intervals, on which can the Mean Value Theorem be applied to <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ?
content.question: <math alttext="open bracket, negative 1, comma 3, close bracket " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> because <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is continuous on <math alttext="open bracket, negative 1, comma 3, close bracket " display="inline"
